results.title: London can take it!
results.creator_credit: Harry Watt, Humphrey Jennings and GPO Film Unit
results.brief_description: London life in the blitz is presented as ‘a series of contrasts between the ordinary and the extraordinary, the casual and the tense, beauty and destruction, stillness and action, silence and noise, light and dark’. This is surrealism based not on symbolic representation of the subconscious but on images of everyday, images transformed by exceptional circumstances of war. These images are public not private. Their power is entirely cultural and social. The commentary by American correspondent Quentin Reynolds interacts in quite a complex way with the images. Primarily intended for North American audiences, a shorter five minute adaptation called Britain Can Take It was screened very successfully in British cinemas and was something of a breakthrough for British documentary.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harry Watt, Humphrey Jennings and GPO Film Unit

results.title: The Living camera, with Paul
results.creator_credit: D.A. Pennebaker, Greg Shuker, R. Leacock, Robert Drew, Drew Associates and Time-Life Broadcast
results.brief_description: Can a murderer become rehabilitated while he sits in death row for nine years awaiting electrocution? If he can, should his sentence be commuted to life? A young Chicago attorney answers “yes” to both questions. He then undergoes the agony and elation of a successful plea to the parole board with famed Louis Nizer at his side. Filmed with hand-held camera and sound recorder.
results.creator_credit_for_label: D.A. Pennebaker, Greg Shuker, R. Leacock, Robert Drew, Drew Associates and Time-Life Broadcast

results.title: Life in her hands
results.creator_credit: Philip Leacock, Frederick Wilson and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: A dramatised account of the training and duties of a hospital nurse in England. The film takes particular psychological problems of a young widow who, after her husband’s death in a car crash, finds emotional and vocational satisfaction in nursing. The film deals mainly with her reactions to the demands of her work and emphasises the social service nature of her profession.

results.title: Lichtenstein in London
results.brief_description: In February 1968, an exhibition of the paintings of the American pop artist Roy Liechtenstein was held at the Tate Gallery in London. This is a film record of the exhibition and both members of the public and Liechtenstein comment on the work displayed. The public were interviewed by Hugh Evans. Roy Liechtenstein’s comments were taken from interviews by Alan Soloman recorded for National Education Television and by David Sylvester recorded for British Broadcasting Corporation.

results.title: Less hours working
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Sue Mogg and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the relevance and value of further education to Australia’s farming community to help them utilise and understand technological developments, changing government policies and increasing costs.

results.title: Legault's place
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Angel, Roman Kroitor, Tom Daly and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The story of an old man and his aging cabin in a new neighbourhood of Montreal. At one time the cabin was surrounded by fields but eventually this changed to an attractive city suburb. Legault’s place became an eye- sore. What happens when the old man is persuaded to sell makes a warm and humorous story.

results.title: League of gentlemen [study extract]
results.creator_credit: Basil Dearden, Michael Relph and Allied Filmmakers
results.brief_description: Colonel Hyde, retired from the Army, launches a new company “Cooperative Removals” dedicated to helping ex-servicemen adjust themselves to civilian life. He recruited seven men into the “league of Gentlemen” who carried out his master-plan. Shows how they succeeded in relieving the Army of enough arms for their purposes. The final robbery required detailed planning, coordination of forces and split-second timing. The group retired one million pounds richer, but they made mistakes and the police finally closed around them. Cast includes Jack Hawkins, Nigel Patrick, Roger Livesey, Richard Attenborough, Bryan Forbes and Keiron More. For film studies students.

results.title: The Ladykillers [study extract]
results.creator_credit: Alexander Mackendrick, Sir Michael Balcon, Ealing Studios and Michael Balcon Productions
results.brief_description: This film is an extract from the film directed by Alexander Mackendrick which includes stars such as Alec Guinness, Cecil Parker, Herbert Lom, Peter Sellers, Frankie Howerd and others. The Professor (Alec Guiness) is making a last minute check on the bank’s procedure for transferring money while the rest of the gang are still at Mrs. Wilberforce’s keeping up the pretence that they are musicians at rehearsal…then working with military precision and split-second timing the gang successfully effect the robbery.

results.title: Ladies and gentlemen...Mr Leonard Cohen
results.creator_credit: Donald Brittain, Don Owen, John Kemeny and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Presents an informal portrait of the Montreal poet, Leonard Cohen, on the platform reading to his audience, at other times alone, or with family or friends. Among his writings are a novel, THE FAVOURED GAME and two books of poems, SPICE BOX OF THE EARTH and FLOWERS FOR HITLER, which are read and quoted avidly by young people in Canada and the United States. (Awards: Toronto; New York; Philadelphia)
